name: EWS for Office 365
description: This app ingests emails from a mailbox in addition to supporting various investigative and containment actions on an Office 365 service

ingest_manner.verbose: During ingestion, should the app get the latest emails or the oldest.

add_body_to_header_artifacts.description: Add Email Body to the Email Artifact

actions.description: Validate the asset configuration for connectivity
actions.verbose: To check the connection and credentials, this action tries to list the email ids of the configured poll_user.

The run query action provides more than one method to search a user's mailbox:
  • Simple Search
    Use the subject and body parameters to search for substring matches. The sender parameter can be used to search for emails from a specific address. However, it has been noticed that a match with the sender email address fails for emails that have been never sent or received, but instead have been created manually as a draft and copied to the searched mailbox. In such cases, an AQS is a better option. If more than one parameter is specified, the search is an And of the given values including the internet_message_id.
    Simple Search implements search filters. More details regarding search filters can be found on this MSDN Link.
  • Query Search
    For a more fine-grained email search, the use of the query parameter is recommended. If this parameter is specified, the subject, internet_message_id, and body parameters are ignored.
    This parameter supports AQS queries to search in a Mailbox. More details regarding AQS keywords supported by Exchange can be found on this MSDN Link.
    Searching with AQS strings does have one notable restriction, however. The AQS search string will only match substrings from the start of a word. If a substring needs to be found in the middle of a word, use a Simple Search.
    Some examples:
    • All emails from user1@contoso.com or user2@contoso.com
      from:user1@contoso.com OR from:user2@contoso.com
    • All emails containing the string free vacations
      body: free vacations
    • This will match an email with subject containing the word Details but not Cadet
      subject:det
If the folder parameter is not specified, each email based folder such as Inbox, Sent, etc. will be searched, including the children (nested) folders.
The action supports searching for a folder that is nested within another.
To search in such a folder, specify the complete path using the '/' (forward slash) as the separator.
For e.g. to search in a folder named phishing which is nested within (is a child of) Inbox, set the value as Inbox/phishing. If a folder name has a literal forward slash in the name escape it with a backslash to differentiate.
NOTE: In some cases, search results may return more emails than are visible in an email client. This is due to emails that have been just deleted, but not yet completely cleaned by the server.

The action supports limiting the number of emails returned using the range parameter. The input should be of the form min_offset-max_offset. The results are always sorted in descending order to place the latest emails at the top. For example to get the latest 10 emails that matched the filter, specify the range as 0-9. If multiple folders are searched for, then the range will be applied for each folder.
So if the folder being searched for example Inbox has a child (nested) folder called phishing and the range specified is 2-10, then the action will return 9 max emails for each folder. If the range parameter is not specified by default the action will use 0-10.

NOTE: The email parameter is required.

Many actions such as delete email and copy email require the Office 365 email ID as input. Many times this value is not easily available, since not many email clients display it. However, every email header has a value called Message-ID assigned to it. It's usually something like <tS10Ncty2SyeJsjdNMsxV+dguQ+jd7RwiFgmZsLN@contoso.com>. Use this as the value (including the < and > chars if present) of internet_message_id parameter and execute the action. The results will contain the Office 365 email ID of an email, which can be used as input for other actions.

This action supports a comma-separated list of message IDs as input, which should be used to delete multiple emails in a single call to the server. The deleted emails are moved to the Deleted Items (trash) folder.

id.description: Message IDs to delete (comma-separated values supported)

email.description: Email of the mailbox owner (used during impersonation)

actions.description: Copy an email to a folder
actions.verbose:
The action supports copying to a folder that is nested within another.
To copy to such a folder, specify the complete path using the '/' (forward slash) as the separator.
For e.g. to copy email to a folder named phishing which is nested within (is a child of) Inbox, set the value as Inbox/phishing. If a folder name has a literal forward slash in the name escape it with a backslash to differentiate.
The action requires the Office 365 email ID as input. Many times this value is not easily available, since not many email clients display it. However, every email header has a value called Message-ID assigned to it. It's usually something like <tS10Ncty2SyeJsjdNMsxV+dguQ+jd7RwiFgmZsLN@contoso.com>. Use this Internet Message ID as input to the run query action to get the Office 365 email ID of an email.
The action will return the ID of the newly copied email in the data path action_result.data.*.new_email_id, however, this value is not available for cross-mailbox or mailbox to public folder copy email actions (please see the documentation of the CopyItem operation on MSDN). However, in such scenarios, do a run query on the new mailbox plus folder with a specific parameter like Internet Message ID to get the Office 365 email ID.

Impersonation

Impersonation plays a big role in the copy email action, for reasons explained in this section, copy email is the only action that overrides the asset config parameter use_impersonation. By default, the action will impersonate the user specified in the email parameter, if impersonation is enabled (by setting the dont_impersonate action parameter to False or Unchecked).
However, depending on the server configuration, this action might fail with an Access Denied error. If an email is being copied from one folder to another in the same mailbox, the action will succeed, however, if the email is being copied from one mailbox's folder to a different mailbox, the impersonated user will require access to both the mailboxes. In this case, the action might require to impersonate a user other than the one specified in the email parameter. In such a scenario use the impersonate_email to specify an alternate email to impersonate.
Set the dont_impersonate parameter to True to disable impersonation all together. This value will override the one configured on the asset. The default value of this param is False.

is_public_folder.description: Mailbox folder is a public folder

actions.description: Move an email to a folder
actions.verbose:
The action supports moving an email to a folder that is nested within another.
To move to such a folder, specify the complete path using the '/' (forward slash) as the separator.
For example, to move an email to a folder named phishing which is nested within Inbox, set the value as Inbox/phishing.
The action requires the exchange email ID as input. Many times this value is not easily available, since not many email clients display it. However, every email header has a value called Message-ID assigned to it. It's usually something like <tS10Ncty2SyeJsjdNMsxV+dguQ+jd7RwiFgmZsLN@contoso.com>. Use this Internet Message ID as input to the run query action to get the exchange email ID of an email.
The action will return the ID of the newly copied email in the data path action_result.data.*.new_email_id, however, this value is not available for cross-mailbox or mailbox to public folder move email actions (please see the documentation of the MoveItem operation on MSDN). However, in such scenarios, do a run query on the new mailbox plus folder with a specific parameter like Internet Message ID to get the Exchange email ID.

Impersonation

Impersonation plays a big role in the move email action, for reasons explained in this section, move email is the only action that overrides the asset config parameter use_impersonation. By default, the action will impersonate the user specified in the email parameter, if impersonation is enabled (by setting the dont_impersonate action parameter to False or Unchecked).
However, depending on the server configuration, this action might fail with an Access Denied error. If an email is being copied from one folder to another in the same mailbox, the action will succeed, however, if the email is being copied from one mailbox's folder to a different mailbox, the impersonated user will require access to both the mailboxes. In this case, the action might require to impersonate a user other than the one specified in the email parameter. In such a scenario use the impersonate_email to specify an alternate email to impersonate.
Set the dont_impersonate parameter to True to disable impersonation all together. This value will override the one configured on the asset. The default value of this param is False.

is_public_folder.description: Mailbox folder is a public folder

actions.description: Add the sender email into the block list
actions.verbose:
This action takes as input an email whose sender will be added to the Block Senders List. The message ID changes after the execution and is a required parameter for request hence undo action would require unique ID. Note that a message from the email address must exist in the user's mailbox before you can add the email address to or remove it from the Blocked Senders List.
  • If the move_to_junk_folder parameter is set to True, the sender of the target email message is added to the blocked sender list and the email message is moved to the Junk Email folder.
  • If the move_to_junk_folder attribute is set to False, the sender of the target email message is added to the blocked sender list and the email message is not moved from the folder.
To view the current Block Senders list, please read the following Powershell articles:
  • https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/exchange/exchange-online/connect-to-exchange-online-powershell/connect-to-exchange-online-powershell?view=exchange-ps
  • https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/antispam-antimalware/Get-MailboxJunkEmailConfiguration?view=exchange-ps

id.description: Message ID to pick the sender of

move_to_junk_folder.description: Should the email be moved to the junk folder

email.description: Email of the mailbox owner (used during impersonation)

example_values: Sender blocked. Message moved to Junk Folder

actions.description: Remove the sender email from the block list
actions.verbose:
This action takes as input an email whose sender will be removed from the Block Senders List. The message ID changes after the execution and is a required parameter for request hence undo action would require unique ID. Note that a message from the email address must exist in the user's mailbox before you can add the email address to or remove it from the Blocked Senders List.
  • If the move_from_junk_folder parameter is set to True, the sender of the target email message is removed from the blocked sender list and the email message is moved from the Junk Email folder.
  • If the move_from_junk_folder attribute is set to False, the sender of the target email message is removed from the blocked sender list and the email message is not moved from the folder.
To view the current Block Senders list, please read the following Powershell articles:
  • https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/exchange/exchange-online/connect-to-exchange-online-powershell/connect-to-exchange-online-powershell?view=exchange-ps
  • https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/antispam-antimalware/Get-MailboxJunkEmailConfiguration?view=exchange-ps

id.description: Message ID to pick the sender of

move_from_junk_folder.description: Should the email be moved out of the junk folder

email.description: Email of the mailbox owner (used during impersonation)

example_values: Sender Unblocked. Message moved out of Junk Folder

actions.description: Get an email from the server
actions.verbose:
Every container that is created by the app has the following values:
  • The container ID that is generated by the Phantom platform.
  • The Source ID that the app equates to the email ID on the server if known or the vault ID if asked to parse from the vault.
  • The raw_email data in the container's data field is set to the RFC822 format of the email.
This action parses email data and if specified create containers and artifacts. The email data to parse is either extracted from the remote server if an email ID is specified, from a Phantom container, if the container_id is specified or from the vault item if the vault_id is specified.
If all three parameters are specified, the action will use the container_id.
The data paths differ depending on where the email data is parsed from.

If parsed from the server:

  • The data path action_result.data.*.t_MimeContent.#text contains the email in RFC822 format but base64 encoded.
  • The data path action_result.data.*.t_Body.#text contains the email body.
  • The widget for this action will render a text version of the email body if possible.
  • If impersonation is enabled on the asset, the email parameter is required, else email will be ignored.

If parsed from the container or vault:

  • The widget does not render the email body.
  • The email headers are listed in a table.

If ingest_email is set to True:

  • The ID of the container created or updated will be set in the action_result.summary.container_id data path
  • The widget will display this ID as Ingested Container ID

Do note that any containers and artifacts created will use the label configured in the asset.
The action will fail if the vault item asked to parse and ingest is not a valid MSG file.

email.description: Email of the mailbox owner (used during impersonation)

container_id.description: Container ID to get email data from

vault_id.description: Vault ID to get email from

example_values: Test user added you to the test-h1 group

actions.description: Get the email addresses that make up a Distribution List
actions.verbose: The group parameter supports as input the email (for e.g. dleng@corp.contoso.com) or the name (for e.g. dleng) of the distribution list. If the recursive parameter is true and if any group in the hierarchy below the group provided in the input parameter points to any group in the parent chain, then the action may take 10-15 minutes to execute because the method calls itself recursively until the maximum depth of recursion is exhausted.

Update an email on the server
actions.verbose: Currently, this action only updates the category and subject of an email. To set multiple categories, please pass a comma-separated list to the category parameter.

email.description: Email of the mailbox owner (used during impersonation)

example_values: Test user added you to the test-h1 group

actions.description: Get message trace from the server
actions.verbose:
The trace email action provides summary information about the processing of email messages that have passed through the Office 365 system for the organization in the last 10 days.

Valid values for the status parameter are:
  • None: The message has no delivery status because it was rejected or redirected to a different recipient.
  • GettingStatus: The message is waiting for status update.
  • Failed: Message delivery was attempted and it failed or the message was filtered as spam or malware, or by transport rules.
  • Pending: Message delivery is underway or was deferred and is being retried.
  • Delivered: The message was delivered to its destination.
  • Expanded: There was no message delivery because the message was addressed to a distribution group and the membership of the distribution was expanded.
  • Quarantined: The message was quarantined.
  • FilteredAsSpam: The message was marked as spam.
The 'start date' and 'end date' parameters are considered optional, but if you provide one, you have to provide the other. i. e. If you provide a 'start date' in the parameter option, you must also specify an 'end date' and vice versa. If the pair is not provided in the query, the default reporting time period is the previous two days.
If 'widget filter' is set to True, the angular brackets will be removed from the Internet Message ID field.

The action supports limiting the number of emails returned using the range parameter. The input should be of the form min_offset-max_offset. If the range parameter is not specified by default the action will fetch all possible data.

Please note that the username and password are required for the 'trace email' action, because it will only use the 'basic auth' for all the cases. Azure authentication workflow will be ignored by this action. The user must have an administrator role for accessing the message trace. For more information about APIs and permissions please visit the official documentation.

sender_address.description: The SMTP email address of the user the message was purportedly from. You can specify multiple values separated by commas.

recipient_address.description: The SMTP email address of the user that the message was addressed to. You can specify multiple values separated by commas.

status.description: The status corresponds to the Detail field of the last processing step recorded for the message. You can specify multiple values separated by commas.

message_trace_id.description: An identifier used to get the detailed message transfer trace information

start_date.description: Start date of the date range

end_date.description: End date of the date range

from_ip.description: The IPv4 or IPv6 address that transmitted the message to the Office 365 email system

to_ip.description: The IPv4 or IPv6 address that the Office 365 email system sent the message to

internet_message_id.description: This parameter filters the results by the Internet Message ID also known as the Client ID

widget_filter.description: Widget Filter to clean certain special character

actions.description: Action handler for the ingest functionality
actions.verbose: Please see sections POLL NOW and Scheduled Polling for more info on how this action is implemented by the app.

container_count.description: Maximum number of emails to ingest
